info.title: F5 Distributed Cloud Services API for ves.io.schema.views.terraform_parameters
info.description:
View Terraform Parameters is set of parameters that are used by terraform scripts 
to instantiate view objects external to volterra

post.description: force delete view object. This can result in staled objects in cloud provider.

401.description: Returned when operation is not authorized

403.description: Returned when there is no permission to access resource

404.description: Returned when resource is not found

409.description: Returned when operation on resource is conflicting with current value

429.description: Returned when operation has been rejected as it is happening too frequently

500.description: Returned when server encountered an error in processing API

503.description: Returned when service is unavailable temporarily

504.description: Returned when server timed out processing request

parameters.description:
Namespace

x-example: "value"
Namespace for the label to be retrieved

parameters.name: view_kind
parameters.description:
Kind of View

x-example: "value"
Kind of view of which terraform parameters are requested e.g. aws_vpc_site, azure_vnet_site

parameters.name: view_name
parameters.description:
Name of view

x-example: "value"
Name of the view for which terraform parameters are requested

ioschemaObjectRefType.description:
This type establishes a 'direct reference' from one object(the referrer) to another(the referred).
Such a reference is in form of tenant/namespace/name for public API and Uid for private API
This type of reference is called direct because the relation is explicit and concrete (as opposed
to selector reference which builds a group based on labels of selectee objects)
ioschemaObjectRefType.title: ObjectRefType

kind.description:
When a configuration object(e.g. virtual_host) refers to another(e.g route)
 then kind will hold the referred object's kind (e.g. "route")

Example: ` "virtual_site"`
kind.title: kind

name.description:
When a configuration object(e.g. virtual_host) refers to another(e.g route)
 then name will hold the referred object's(e.g. route's) name.

Example: ` "contactus-route"`
name.title: name

namespace.description:
When a configuration object(e.g. virtual_host) refers to another(e.g route)
 then namespace will hold the referred object's(e.g. route's) namespace.

Example: ` "ns1"`
namespace.title: namespace

tenant.description:
When a configuration object(e.g. virtual_host) refers to another(e.g route)
 then tenant will hold the referred object's(e.g. route's) tenant.

Example: ` "acmecorp"`
tenant.title: tenant

uid.description:
When a configuration object(e.g. virtual_host) refers to another(e.g route)
 then uid will hold the referred object's(e.g. route's) uid.

Example: ` "d15f1fad-4d37-48c0-8706-df1824d76d31"`
uid.title: uid

type_url.description:
A URL/resource name that uniquely identifies the type of the serialized
protocol buffer message. This string must contain at least
one "/" character. The last segment of the URL's path must represent
the fully qualified name of the type (as in
`path/google.protobuf.Duration`). The name should be in a canonical form
(e.g., leading "." is not accepted).

In practice, teams usually precompile into the binary all types that they
expect it to use in the context of Any. However, for URLs which use the
scheme `http`, `https`, or no scheme, one can optionally set up a type
server that maps type URLs to message definitions as follows:

* If no scheme is provided, `https` is assumed.
* An HTTP GET on the URL must yield a [google.protobuf.Type][]
  value in binary format, or produce an error.
* Applications are allowed to cache lookup results based on the
  URL, or have them precompiled into a binary to avoid any
  lookup. Therefore, binary compatibility needs to be preserved
  on changes to types. (Use versioned type names to manage
  breaking changes.)

Note: this functionality is not currently available in the official
protobuf release, and it is not used for type URLs beginning with
type.googleapis.com.

Schemes other than `http`, `https` (or the empty scheme) might be
used with implementation specific semantics.

value.description: Must be a valid serialized protocol buffer of the above specified type.

schemaConditionType.description:
Conditions are used in the object status to describe the current state of the
object, e.g. Ready, Succeeded, etc.
schemaConditionType.title: ConditionType

hostname.description: Hostname of the instance of the site that sent the status
hostname.title: hostname

last_update_time.description: Last time the condition was updated
last_update_time.title: last_update_time

reason.description:
x-reason: "Insufficient memory in data plane"
 A human readable string explaining the reason for reaching this condition

Example: ` "value"`
reason.title: reason

service_name.description: Name of the service that sent the status
service_name.title: service name

status.description:
Status of the condition
 "Success" Validtion has succeded. Requested operation was successful.
 "Failed"  Validation has failed.
 "Incomplete" Validation of configuration has failed due to missing configuration.
 "Installed" Validation has passed and configuration has been installed in data path or K8s
 "Down" Configuration is operationally down. e.g. down interface
 "Disabled" Configuration is administratively disabled i.e. ObjectMetaType.Disable = true.
 "NotApplicable" Configuration is not applicable e.g. tenant service_policy_set(s) in system namespace are not applicable on REs

Example: ` "Failed"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.in: [\"Success\",\"Failed\",\"Incomplete\",\"Installed\",\"Down\",\"Disabled\",\"NotApplicable\"]
status.title: status

type.description:
Type of the condition
 "Validation" represents validation user given configuration object
 "Operational" represents operational status of a given configuration object

Example: ` "Operational"`

Validation Rules:
  ves.io.schema.rules.string.in: [\"Validation\",\"Operational\"]
type.title: type

schemaStatusMetaType.description: StatusMetaType is metadata that all status must have.
schemaStatusMetaType.title: StatusMetaType

creation_timestamp.description:
creation_timestamp is when the status object was created. It is used to find/tie-break
 for latest status object from same origin
creation_timestamp.title: creation_timestamp

creator_class.description:
Class of creator which created this StatusObject. This will be service's DNS FQDN.
 This will be set by the system based on client certificate information.

Example: ` "ver.re1.int.ves.io"`
creator_class.title: creator_class

creator_id.description:
ID of creator which created this StatusObject. This will be a concrete identifier for service (e.g.
 identifying the environment also). This will be set by the system based on client certificate
 information

Example: ` "ver-instance-1"`
creator_id.title: creator_id

status_id.description:
status_id is a field used by the generator to distinguish (if necessary) between two status
 objects for the same config object from the same site and same service and potentially same
 daemon(creator-id)
status_id.title: status_id

uid.description:
uid is the unique in time and space value for a StatusObject.

Example: ` "d15f1fad-4d37-48c0-8706-df1824d76d31"`
uid.title: uid

vtrp_id.description: Origin of this status exchanged by VTRP.
vtrp_id.title: vtrp_id

vtrp_stale.description: Indicate whether mars deems this object to be stale via graceful restart timer information
vtrp_stale.title: vtrp_stale

schemaStatusPublishType.description:
StatusPublishType is all possible publish operations on a StatusObject

 - STATUS_DO_NOT_PUBLISH: Do Not Publish

Do not propagate this status to user. This could be because status is only informational
 - STATUS_PUBLISH: Publish

Propagate this status up to user as it might be actionable
schemaStatusPublishType.title: StatusPublishType

terraform_parametersApplyStageState.title:
- APPLIED: x-displayName: "Applied"
 - APPLY_ERRORED: x-displayName: "Apply errored"
 - APPLY_INIT_ERRORED: x-displayName: "Apply init errored"
 - APPLYING: x-displayName: "Applying"
 - APPLY_PLANNING: x-displayName: "Apply planning"
 - APPLY_PLAN_ERRORED: x-displayName: "Apply plan errored"
 - APPLY_QUEUED: x-displayName: "Apply queued"

Example: ` "value"`

tf_stdout.description: The stdout of terraform apply command.

tf_plan_output.description:
Terraform "plan" command output. Terraform performs a refresh, unless explicitly disabled, and then
 determines what actions are necessary to achieve the desired state specified in the configuration files.

Example: ` "value"`
tf_plan_output.title: tf_plan_output

terraform_parametersRollbackState.title:
- ROLLBACK_SUCCESSFUL: x-displayName: "Rollback successful"
 - ROLLBACK_ERRORED: x-displayName: "Rollback errored"
 - ROLLBACK_NOT_REQUIRED: x-displayName: "Rollback not required"

terraform_parametersRunAction.description:
Terraform action to be performed for a given view e.g. plan, apply

Apply action used to apply the changes required to reach the desired state of the configuration
Plan action is a convenient way to check whether the execution plan for a set of changes matches your expectations without making any changes to real resources or to the state
DESTROY action is used to destroy the Terraform-managed infrastructure
terraform_parametersRunAction.title: Terraform Action

terraform_parametersRunRequest.description: perform terraform actions for a given view. Supported actions are apply and plan.
terraform_parametersRunRequest.title: Run Terraform Action for view

namespace.description:
Namespace for the label to be retrieved

Example: ` "value"`

Kind of view of which terraform parameters are requested e.g. aws_vpc_site, azure_vnet_site

Example: ` "value"`
view_kind.title: Kind of View

view_name.description:
Name of the view for which terraform parameters are requested

Example: ` "value"`
view_name.title: Name of view

conditions.title: conditions

object_refs.title: object_refs
